entry.title: Ancient Indian Computing
entry.content:
Binary Values

1 and 0s

Pneumonic

The binary notation is a mirror images of the modern binary notation

Prashtra

Given a binary value, what is the next in sequence? Algorithm shown

Sankya

Given a binary notation, what is it value? Pingala provides an efficient algorithm

Nasta

Find the nth binary notation in the 4 digit binary system

Uddishta

Given a number, find its metre (value)

Lagagriya

Pyramid way to calculate combinations

References

Pingala's Chandahsastra

entry.title: ROS Basics
entry.content:
ROS Basics

Package

  • all the source files to execute code
  • src
    • source code
      • CMakeLists
  • information to execute the code.
  • add_executable - location of the source code
  • add_dependencies - hooks to the dependencies needed by your code

  • catkin workspace

    • default workspace for all package in ROS

  • roscd

    • change directory to a location in a package

entry.title: MUSHR Battery
entry.content:
Battery

Battery is one of the most important elements in a self driving car. If the JETSON NANO is not powered long enough, you cannot TEST, DEBUG the car. I tried the NIiMH batteries suggested by the MUSHR team, but due to lmited battery knowledge ended up draining them and hence making it unusable!! So after thorough research, I ended buying LIPO BATTERY pack here and battery charger here

Warning: DO NOT IGNORE THIS SECTION. Having a good battery and taking good care of will save you ton of time downstream when you are stuck in code debugging or testing on track.

FAQs

Why LIPOS Battery (instead of NiMH)?

The advantages of lithium batteries compared to NiMH batteries are undeniable. The weight/power ratio in LiPo batteries is significantly better. LiPo batteries are noticeably lighter and they can store the same amount or more energy relative to their capacity than NiMH batteries. Also,

  • It costs the same as NiMH
  • Using a smart battery charger, control the charge and use it for years!!

Ok, I agree LIPOS are good. What the hell is BALANCE CHARGE vs FAST CHARGE vs SLOW CHARGE vs STORAGE CHARGE? Which one do I use?

  • BALANCE CHARGE Charges both the cells inside the battery equally. Use this setting 99.99% of the time.

  • STORAGE CHARGE Charges the cells in such a way so that you can store them for months (and hence the name). LIPOS if they are allowed to drain, will drain completely and not work this requiring them to jump start.

  • FAST and SLOW CHARGE Charges fast and slow as name suggest. Used in certain special cases.

Ok, basic question, How do I connect and charge?

Do I ever going to need buy NiMH Batteries in the HARDWARE list section ? No

Low Voltage - If you keep the lipo batteries unused too long, the voltage drains and results in an "low voltage error" when you charge them back in a battery

  • Use the NiMh option and charge the LIPO battey. this acts as a booster and increases voltage rapidly.
  • Increase above 4A and keep it right around 5A

    Important :After 5A, after you feel its stabliizies around 5A mark, UNPLUG, Dont get greedy.- charge LIPO using LIPO options as normal and now the LOW VOLTAGE message will be gone.

Here is good video about various battery sources for your JETSON NANO

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B4afWen1CsY

Jetson Booting Problem

Jetson sometime does not bootup when you set the voltage to 5V in the BUCK Converter

Slightly raising the output voltage of the buck converter (say to 5.2V) It is possible that when the Jetson Nano boots, the sudden required load current causes the buck converter's output voltage to momentarily drop below the Nano's minimum required voltage, so having it output a slightly higher voltage to compensate might allow it to successfully boot. Note that the Jetson Nano is spec'd to handle up to 5.25V, and also has an overvoltage protection circuit

References

Connect to RVIZ from the linux image

Low Voltage Video

entry.title: Reinforcement Learning
entry.content:
Reinforcement Learning Basics

  • Unlike the unsuperivsed or supervised learning algorithms, it is used in dynamic env

  • There are 2 entities involved:

    • AGENT : Software involved in getting input and executing actions
    • Environment : House that Agent is in

  • Input

    • Take a set of observations (or states)

  • Process (or policy)

    • Figures out the right set of actions
    • If we used "deep learning" for this, then it becomes deep reinforcement learning

  • Output

    • Right set of commands to follow
  • Feedback
    • It the output received positive feedback, great, keep in mind and repeat when possible
    • If not, change

Things to keep in mind in RL

Value vs Reward

  • Value = long term benefits
  • Reward = Immediate feedback
  • If its too long term, env has changed, your algorithm or function is obsolete
  • too short term, its not a visionary and missed crucial opportunities

Explore vs Exploit

  • Agent explores new env and learn ==> updates policy
  • Agent exploits exising env, fine tunes and gets good at it!
  • Our problem : balance exploit vs explore

Dynamic Programming

  • Divides a problem into multiple sub problems
  • Solves the simplest sub problem first and then does this recurisively until all of them are solved

entry.title: Pandas and its SQL Equivalent
entry.content:
JOIN 

SELECT * FROM TABLE a join TABLE_B b on a.column1 = b.column2

pd.merge(
left = left_dataframe, 
right = right_dataframe, 
how ='left'                 # what kind of join? right/left/outer
suffixes=('_fa', '_ag'),    # by default, it will _x, _y to the common columns between the tables. This will add meaningful suffixes
left_on=['CustomField19'],  # left table columns to join
right_on=['AssetId'])       # right table column to join

pd.merge(
left = left_dataframe, 
right = right_dataframe, 
how ='left'                 # what kind of join? right/left/outer
suffixes=('_fa', '_ag'),    # by default, it will _x, _y to the common columns between the tables. This will add meaningful suffixes
on=['CustomField19'],       # common columns to join. it will intersect for values which are diff

RENAME 

sp_rename(table.colA, table.ColB)

df.rename(columns = {"colA": "colB"}, inplace=True)

WHERE 

SELECT * FROM table WHERE colName = Value

df[[df.ColName == Value]]

DISTINCT 

SELECT DISTINCT Col1, Col2 FROM table WHERE colName = Value

df[['col1', 'col2']].drop_duplicates()

UDPATE column from another column 

UPDATE tbl
Set ColA = ColB
Where ColC = 'somevalue'

df['ColA'] = df.apply(lambda x: x['ColB'] if x['ColC']="somevalue" else x['ColA'], axis = 1]

RANK 

select row_number() OVER (order by col) from TableA

df["ColA"].rank(method="max")

default = average
possible : max, min, first, dense

References

updates in pandas

entry.title: Remote Jupyter Notebook
entry.content:
Setup Remote Jupyter Notebook

Useful in cases where you want to access jupyter notebooks from MAC or WINDOWS but want to setup UBUNTU servers with jupyter notebooks.

CREATE EXEC SCRIPT

  • CREATE jupyter-startup.sh 
source ~/miniconda3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh
conda activate YOUR_CONDA_VIRTUAL_ENVIRONMENT
jupyter notebook

CREATE JUPYTER SERVICE

  • CREATE a following jupyter service in your home directory
  • COPY the file to this destination ==> /etc/systemd/system/jupyter.service
[Unit]

Description=Jupyter Notebook Service Description

[Service]

Type=simple

PIDFile=/run/jupyter.pid

ExecStart=/home/YOUR_USER_NAME/jupyter-startup.sh 

User=YOUR_USER_NAME

Group=YOUR_USER_NAME

Restart=always

RestartSec=10

[Install]

WantedBy=multi-user.target

- sudo systemctl enable jupyter.service
- sudo systemctl daemon-reload
- sudo systemctl restart jupyter.service

Important :Pick either option 1 or 2 (but not both).

SSH Tunnel (option 1)

1) Setup a password to the notebook server so that we dont have to provide token every single time. On the remote server, do the following

jupyter notebook password
#Enter password:  ****
#Verify password: ****
#[NotebookPasswordApp] Wrote hashed password to /Users/<<you>>/.jupyter/jupyter_notebook_config.json

2) Run SSH tunnel to setup a link on the local host

Pick any port number for LOCAL_PORT. You may need to enter a passphrase.

ssh -N -f -L localhost:<LOCAL_PORT>:localhost:8080 username@remotemachine -p <<PORT ID>> -v

3) Type http://localhost:8888/tree in your local browser to access the jupyter notebook setup remotely.

PUBLIC URL (option 2)

CONFIG JUPYTER NOTEBOOK

  • Create Jupyter Notebook Configuration
jupyter notebook –generate-config
CREATE PASSWORD and CERTIFICATES
  • First generate a new password to login
from notebook.auth import passwd
import IPython

passwd()

Enter password: ········
Verify password: ········

'sha1:6ed7a3ec3487:57c304ac1ba182fa7c160d2fcac788a2c376cb5f'
  • Generate the certificate file. It will be used in the configuration step
openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout mykey.key -out mycert.pem

EDIT NOTEBOOK CONFIGURATION FILES 
cd .jupyter
nano jupyter_notebook_config.py

  • Open the configuration file and edit as follows

    • c.NotebookApp.allow_origin = '*'
    • c.NotebookApp.allow_remote_access = True
    • c.NotebookApp.certfile = 'YOUR_CERTIFICATE_FILE'
    • c.NotebookApp.ip = '0.0.0.0'
    • c.NotebookApp.open_browser = False
    • c.NotebookApp.password = u''</li>
    • c.NotebookApp.port = ANY_PORT_YOU_LIKE
      • </ul> </li> </ul>

      EDIT FIREWALL RULES (if needed) 

      sudo ufw allow from <<IP ADDRESS>>
      </div> </div> </div>

      References

      • Config Jupyter Notebook
      • Config Jupyter Notebook 2
      • Create Jupyter Service
      • Create Jupyter Service 2
      • Configure Linux firewall
      </div>

entry.title: AGILE SAFe Training - Notes
entry.content:
Introducing Scrum in SAFe

  • User Stories

    • Small unit of value
    • it has to be user driven
    • I am driver, wanting to do this, that’s adds "this" business value
    • It needs to have
      • CARDS
      • CONVERSATION
      • CONFIRMATION
    • Personas as Representative User

  • Features

    • bigger chunk of user stories
    • single value stream of work
    • typically achieved under a quarter

  • Capability

    • multiple streams of work

  • Velocity

    • The sum of the all the story points that are completed by the SCRUM team in the iteration
    • If they finish 50% of a story, DO NOT take 50% of story point to calculate velocity
    • Its either DONE or NOT DONE

  • Epics

    • not same as projects
    • work of substantial value to the organization
    • can run into mulitple PI's
    • does not have start and end time
    • Define MVP clearly
    • Try to achieve them, if you cannot, pivot and rewrite epics
    • Refer below diagram

  • Architecture Runaway

    • Achieve the near-term features without excessive redesign and delays
    • It will spike up and down
    • Imagine an aircraft, needing to land after exit

  • Enablers

    • Architectural Enabler

      • Improve Perf
      • Becomes Non-Functional-Requirement (NFR) after implementation

    • Infra Enabler

      • CI/CD

  • Difference Between SAFe and SCRUM Terminology

Important: Cadence and Synchronization are the key constructs to delivering continuous value

Characterizing the role of the Scrum Master

  • Role of a SCRUM Master

    • Coach the team with AGILE SCRUM process
    • Facilitate problem solving
    • Protect them from external influence of stakeholders
    • Represent in SOS (Scrum of Scrums)
    • Helps in Coordination with other team (but responsibility of everyone in the AGILE team)
    • Acts as SERVANT leader
      • The one who knows that his/her own growth comes from facilitating the growth of others
    • Ask Powerful questions
      • surfaces hidden assumptions

  • SCRUM of SCRUMS (SOS) = twice a week, then cut down

  • RTE - Release train engineer

    • Manager for scrum masters

  • Shift from old behaviors like ===> new behaviors

    • Driving towards an answer ==> become a facilitator
    • Knowing the answer ===> Letting the team find their own way
    • Directing ===> Guiding

Experiencing PI Planning

  • PI Planning

    • Top 10 features as input
    • PI objectives
    • or else do not start

  • User-less stores

    • DB ==> front end

  • Time is not EQUAL story points

    • relative
    • pick a base and measure against it

  • Never start sprints on Monday/and end on fridays

  • PI planning

    • <>iteration planning
    • assign to people. (atleast team)
    • atleast 2 stories so that we hit the ground running

IP (innovation planning) iteration

  • Innovation
  • No testing
  • No Bug fixes
  • No System Integration

If we dont do this...

  • Tech debt grows
  • People burn out
  • No time to improve
    Warning: Anti-Patterns in Estimations
    - Pressure by stakeholders to loqwer estimations
    • Only few people participate
    • NOt using adjusted fibo scale
      Warning: Anti-Patterns for Breakout Sessions
      - Too much time spent on each story
    • No plan at the end of the timebox
      Warning: Anti-Patterns for PI Planning
      - Pressure on teams to overcommit
    • Team under commits due to over failure
    • Over-planning ahead of time

Facilitating Iteration Execution

  • Iteration Planning
    • consists of 4 steps (PDCA: Plan, Do, Check, Adjust)
      • Iteration Planning
      • Iteration Execution
      • Iteration Retrospective
      • Iteration Review
        Warning: Anti-Patterns for Iteration Progress
        - No input from SoS
        • Teams unwilling to edit objectives mid-PI

  • IP Iteration (Special Type)

    • Innovation purposes
    • NO testing
    • NO bug fixes
    • NO system integration
    • If we dont this iteration, then tech debt grows
    • Burn out among people

  • Daily stand ups

    • 15 mins
    • use the next 15 min for stay-behind
      Warning: Anti-Patterns for Iteration review
      - Focusing on only what to improve and not what to preserve

Finishing the PI

  • System demo is given to the stakeholders (May include multiple demo)

  • Quantatitive measurement (Actual vs Planned)

  • Problem solving workshop (Retro at a high level)

    Warning: Anti-Patterns
    - Only PO presents in the system demo

  • No actionable feature improvements created
  • Improvements are not shown

Misc

  • What is the basis for most team conflicts?
    • Lack of leadership
  • How are the 5 whys used?
    • To identify a root cause(s) of a problem
